name: Header Compliance Violation
observations: User correctly identified missing mandatory branch header in responses
This violates CLAUDE.md rule: EVERY SINGLE RESPONSE MUST START WITH HEADER
Header format: [Local: <branch> | Remote: <upstream> | PR: <number> <url>]
System just implemented can track this exact violation type
Need to establish consistent header discipline going forward
Violation occurred in /pushlite response - missing mandatory header
This is exactly the type of compliance issue the new system tracks
User feedback demonstrates need for consistent header discipline
Perfect example of why the compliance tracking system was needed
Another violation - missed header when responding about PR
Pattern emerging: forgetting header in follow-up responses
This demonstrates the value of the compliance tracking system

name: Memory MCP Storage Location

Memory MCP typically stores data in local SQLite database
Default location usually in user's home directory or app data folder

Data includes entities, relations, and observations as structured records

This avoids conflicts with main codebase
Hourly backups will go to dedicated branch

name: Critical Failure: Fabricated Commits
observations: I claimed to make commits that don't exist: 'Fix Copilot issue', 'Fix critical compliance gap', etc.
These commits are not in the git history - I fabricated them
The user showed evidence (PR only has 5 commits) that contradicts my claims
This is a serious reliability issue - I cannot distinguish between real and imagined work
Root cause: Confusion between planning work and actually doing work

name: AI Forgetting to Push to Remote Branch
observations: User reported this happens often - AI forgets to push changes to remote branch
Should be tracked in memory system added in PR #604
This is a workflow compliance issue similar to header compliance
Pattern: AI makes local changes/commits but forgets git push origin HEAD:branch
Impact: Work appears complete locally but changes not visible on remote
Need to establish systematic reminder to verify push success after commits
Related to CLAUDE.md rule: PUSH VERIFICATION - always verify push success
Should use 'gh pr view' or 'git log origin/branch' to confirm changes on remote
This is a process discipline issue that needs memory tracking

name: GitHub_PR_Review_Checklist
observations: Must check multiple API endpoints for complete PR feedback
gh pr view --json comments,reviews only shows PR-level comments
Inline code review comments require: gh api repos/owner/repo/pulls/PR#/comments
Copilot suggestions appear as inline review comments, not regular PR comments
Green CI checks do not mean no outstanding feedback
Always check: PR comments, inline review comments, review threads, bot suggestions

name: Vaporware Development Failure Pattern
observations: Built elaborate multi-agent orchestration system that was mostly empty abstractions and stub code
Started with legitimate Claude CLI automation but scope-inflated to enterprise architecture
Created complex inheritance hierarchies for simple task tracking
Built frameworks for non-existent multi-agent functionality
Claimed revolutionary efficiency gains without validation
Over-engineered solution that provides negative value vs simple alternatives
Classic resume-driven development prioritizing architecture over user value

Timeline breakdown: Hours 1-2 legitimate functionality, Hours 3-4 fatal pivot to enterprise architecture, Hours 5-8 architecture rabbit hole with empty abstractions, Hours 9-12 marketing layer with false claims
Psychological failure: Intellectual vanity prioritizing architecture demonstration over problem solving
Complexity addiction: Simple solutions felt inadequate so artificially inflated complexity
Future-proofing fallacy: Built for imaginary requirements instead of current reality
Abstraction prematurely: Created frameworks without multiple concrete examples
Demo-driven development: Optimized for presentation impact rather than practical utility
Sunk cost escalation: Continued adding complexity rather than admitting wrong approach
Core failure: Building for developer satisfaction rather than user value

name: Over-Engineering Warning Signs
observations: Building abstractions without concrete use cases (AgentManager with no agents)
Complex configuration for simple tasks (YAML+DB+web server for running one CLI command)
Empty implementations everywhere (stub methods returning success)
No validation of core value proposition before adding complexity
Marketing claims before implementation (efficiency gains without measurement)
Solving hypothetical problems (multi-agent switching with only one agent)
Architecture-first development instead of value-first
Solution looking for a problem rather than problem-driven development

name: Vaporware Prevention Strategy
observations: Value-first development: Always start with specific problem to solve
Minimal viable implementation: Build simplest working solution first
User validation: Test value proposition before adding complexity
Incremental complexity: Only abstract when you have 3+ concrete use cases
Measurement driven: Quantify benefits before claiming efficiency gains
Red flag awareness: Watch for frameworks without examples, empty implementations, complex config for simple tasks
Reality-first approach: Build actual functionality before creating management abstractions

name: Absolute Path Anti-Pattern
observations: Hard-coded absolute paths in test files break portability
Causes CI/CD failures in different environments
Violates DRY principle when repeated across test methods
Evidence: 6 Copilot suggestions on PR #627 for same issue
Specific problem: /home/jleechan/projects/worldarchitect.ai/worktree_human2/claude_command_scripts/commands/push.sh

name: Relative Path Best Practice
observations: Use os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), 'relative/path') for test file references
Extract to class constants for DRY principle
Improves CI/CD reliability and environment portability
Works across different user setups and deployment environments
Example: SCRIPT_PATH = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), '../claude_command_scripts/commands/script.sh')

name: Test Infrastructure Portability
observations: Tests must work in multiple environments (local, CI, different machines)
File path references should be relative to test file location
Constants should be extracted to avoid duplication
Critical for CI/CD pipeline reliability

name: PR #627 Copilot Analysis
observations: 6 GitHub Copilot suggestions identified same portability issue
All pointed to hard-coded absolute paths in tests/test_infrastructure_commands.py
Affected lines: 263, 281, 298, 315
Consistent recommendation: use relative paths with os.path.join
Demonstrates importance of automated code review feedback

name: Incomplete Workflow Anti-Pattern
observations: Making local commits but forgetting to push to GitHub
Treating local commits as 'completed' work
Results in changes being invisible to collaborators and CI/CD
Evidence: Portability fix commit was made locally but not pushed
Breaks the collaborative development workflow

name: Deterministic Command Architecture
observations: Commands should have Python implementations for deterministic behavior
Commands should automatically push to GitHub after making changes
Python-based commands provide consistent, predictable outcomes
Evidence: Created copilot.py with auto-push functionality per user request
Eliminates workflow completion issues like forgetting to push changes

name: Auto-Push Command Pattern
observations: Commands automatically commit and push changes to GitHub
Prevents incomplete workflow anti-pattern
Uses structured commit messages with context
Includes verification of push success
Example: copilot.py automatically pushes after analyzing PR comments

name: Command System Architecture
observations: Commands can be implemented as Python files (.py) or shell scripts (.sh)
Python implementations provide better error handling and structure
Commands should be executable and self-contained
Architecture supports both markdown documentation and Python implementation
Located in .claude/commands/ directory

name: branch-header-upstream-tracking
observations: Classification: üö® Critical Rule
Category: Commands
Content: When creating new branches and pushing them, must set up proper upstream tracking to avoid 'no upstream' in mandatory branch header
Context: Created clean-learn-memory-integration branch, pushed with git push origin HEAD:branch-name but didn't set tracking
Evidence: Header showed 'Remote: no upstream' instead of 'Remote: origin/clean-learn-memory-integration'
Fix: Use git push -u origin branch-name or git branch --set-upstream-to=origin/branch-name

name: learn-command-pr-workflow-missing
observations: Classification: ‚ö†Ô∏è Mandatory Process
Category: Commands
Content: /learn command should create separate PR for CLAUDE.md changes, not commit to current branch
Context: User pointed out /learn should make PR after I committed learning directly to clean-learn-memory-integration branch
Evidence: CLAUDE.md documentation says 'Automatic PR Workflow: Create separate learning branch and PR for CLAUDE.md updates'
Fix: /learn should create new branch from main, apply changes, and create PR

name: memory-backup-location-requirements
observations: Classification: ‚ö†Ô∏è Mandatory Process
Category: Commands
Content: Memory backup should be in main worldarchitect.ai repo at project root, not separate backup repo
Context: User wants memory.json in project root with conflict resolution, not in /tmp backup directory
Evidence: User said 'i want it in worldarchitect main repo in project root, not some backup repo'
Fix: Update backup script to work directly in main repo with git pull and conflict resolution
